title: Hemis Festival
hero_image_alt: Monks performing Cham dance at Hemis Monastery
short_description: A colorful celebration of Tibetan Buddhism in Ladakh, featuring the sacred masked 'Cham' dances.
long_description:
Held at the Hemis Gompa, the largest and richest monastery in Ladakh, this two-day festival celebrates the birth anniversary of Guru Padmasambhava (Guru Rinpoche), the founder of Tibetan Buddhism. The courtyard of the monastery becomes a stage for the 'Cham' dance.

Lamas (monks) dressed in vibrant silk brocade robes and wearing terrifying masks representing deities and demons perform slow, rhythmic dances to the sound of cymbals, long horns (dung-chen), and drums. The dances enact the triumph of good over evil. Once every 12 years (Year of the Monkey), a massive two-story high 'Thangka' (religious scroll) is unfurled, making it exponentially more crowded and auspicious.
significance: Celebrates Guru Padmasambhava's victory over evil forces.
key_rituals: Unfurling the Thangka: Only every 12 years (Next: 2028).

calendar.lunar_reference: 10th day of the Lunar Tibetan month

top_places.title: Hemis Monastery, Ladakh
top_places.best_to_experience: Arrive early (6 AM) to get a seat in the courtyard.

practical_info.dress_tips: Modest clothing covering legs and arms. Sunglasses and sunscreen are vital due to high altitude UV.
practical_info.safety_tips: Acclimatize in Leh for 2 days before heading to Hemis to avoid Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS).
practical_info.accessibility_notes: Not wheelchair friendly; lots of stairs.

faqs.a: Indians need an Inner Line Permit (ILP) for some areas in Ladakh, but Hemis is generally accessible. Foreigners need a Protected Area Permit (PAP) for restricted areas.
